diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can lead to acute pericarditis, neurological symptoms including delirium, skin manifestations such as erythematous-violaceous rashes, pericardial effusion, and renal involvement manifesting as proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily affecting joints, it can also cause pericarditis, systemic symptoms like skin rashes (erythematous-violaceous), and pericardial effusion. Renal involvement could lead to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.reason: Common viruses can cause acute pericarditis and pericardial effusion. In severe cases, systemic involvement could theoretically lead to delirium and kidney issues like proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reason: This disease might cause symptoms similar to lupus and other connective tissue diseases, including pericarditis, skin manifestations, and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.reason: Scleroderma could lead to cardiac and skin manifestations, and it may indirectly cause renal crisis leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily affecting the heart valves, it can cause pericardial effusion, systemic symptoms that might include delirium and skin signs, and kidney damage reflected by proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus
diagnoses.reason: Certain medications can induce a lupus-like disease, causing symptoms such as pericarditis, skin changes, and potential renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reason: TB can cause pericarditis and pericardial effusion. Disseminated TB might lead to systemic complications that could present as delirium and kidney damage, including proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Cancer-associated Pericarditis
diagnoses.reason: Certain cancers can cause pericarditis and pericardial effusion. Cancer and its treatments can also cause a broad range of systemic effects, including skin changes and kidney damage.

diagnoses.name: Uremic Pericarditis
diagnoses.reason: Seen in severe renal failure; causes acute pericarditis and pericardial effusion. Given that proteinuria is a sign of renal disease, this could be a late presentation of chronic kidney disease.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Viral infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)

Cancer (such as lymphoma or lung cancer)
Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia
Cancer (various types, including lung cancer and lymphomas)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if not secondary to another diagnosis)
Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Epstein-Barr Virus)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Schizophrenia (in the context of acute psychosis)
Evans syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can cause a wide range of symptoms, including seizures (CNS involvement), fever, synovitis (joint inflammation), nephritis (kidney inflammation), and proteinuria (protein in the urine), which are consistent with lupus nephritis.

Conditions like Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis can present with systemic features such as fever, renal involvement (nephritis, proteinuria), and rarely neurologic manifestations like seizures. Inflammatory conditions like synovitis could also be present.

Can cause fever, nephritis due to immune complex deposition (embolic kidney involvement), proteinuria as part of renal involvement, and less commonly, septic emboli can lead to seizures. Synovitis is less directly associated but can occur in reactive arthritis secondary to the infection.

Following streptococcal infection, rheumatic fever can present with fever, migratory polyarthritis (which can be mistaken for synovitis in a broader sense), and less commonly, central nervous system involvement, presenting as Sydenham's chorea rather than seizures. It can also cause nephritis.

This condition follows a streptococcal infection and presents with signs of nephritis and proteinuria. Fever can be a part of the initial presentation, and while seizures and synovitis are less common, they can be associated with severe cases due to hypertension or immune-mediated inflammation.

CNS involvement in tuberculosis can cause seizures. This disease can also present with fever, and in rare cases, can mimic vasculitis causing synovitis or affect the kidneys leading to nephritis and proteinuria.

This is a vasculitis syndrome with systemic involvement. Patients may present with fever, and it can affect the brain causing neurological symptoms including seizures. Kidney involvement can lead to nephritis and proteinuria, and arthritis or synovitis is commonly seen.
Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that can present with fever, neurosarcoidosis (which can lead to seizures), kidney involvement (nephritis, proteinuria), and joint involvement (synovitis).
Associated with renal failure (nephritis, proteinuria), and can involve the central nervous system, potentially leading to seizures. Fever is common, but synovitis is not a typical feature.

Similar to Rheumatic Fever, this condition represents an inflammatory reaction to a Group A Streptococcal infection, presenting with fever, arthritis (which might be misinterpreted as synovitis), nephritis, and on rare occasions, seizures due to central nervous involvement.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A skin disease that causes red, itchy scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, trunk, and scalp. Psoriasis is a chronic disease that often comes and goes. The main goal of treatment is to stop the skin cells from growing so quickly.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: An umbrella term for chronic inflammation of the digestive tract, primarily including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Symptoms may include diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss, along with extraintestinal manifestations like skin and nail problems.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. Over time, this reaction damages the small intestine's lining and prevents absorption of some nutrients. Symptoms include diarrhea, bloating, gas, anemia, and growth issues.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body (cross-reactivity). Common symptoms include arthritis, urinary problems, and eye inflammation. Skin and nail changes are also possible.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when the body's immune system attacks its tissues and organs. Inflammation caused by lupus can affect many different body systems, including joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms include fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, and depression. Thyroid dysfunction can also lead to hair, skin, and nail changes.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth. Sjögren's syndrome often accompanies other immune system disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus. Systemic symptoms can include fatigue, joint pain, and skin disorders.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a lack of healthy red blood cells due to a deficiency in iron. It can cause fatigue, pallor, and shortness of breath. In some cases, it can also lead to attention and mood disorders due to the body's reduced oxygen-carrying capacity.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis C
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that causes liver inflammation, sometimes leading to serious liver damage. Extrahepatic manifestations may include skin rashes, arthritis, and cognitive changes like attention deficits.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from not enough vitamin B12 in the body. It can lead to neurological and psychological problems, including memory difficulties, cognitive decline, mood swings, and general weakness.

diagnoses: Anosmia/Hyposmia (as dysosmia relates to smell disorders)
Iron Deficiency Anemia (can coexist or contribute to hypothyroidism or mood lability)
Chronic Kidney Disease-Mineral and Bone Disorder

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in certain blood-forming cells of the bone marrow. It can lead to high levels of white cells, including basophils, and can cause sweating, and potentially influence vision and electrolyte balances.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the marrow to make too many red blood cells, which can lead to thickened blood, affecting vision and causing sweating. It can also lead to high basophil counts and abnormal electrolytes.

diagnoses.name: Premenstrual Syndrome (PMS)
diagnoses.description: A complex condition with a wide range of symptoms that can affect women in the days before their menstruation, including menorrhagia, difficulty focusing, and sweats. Electrolyte imbalance may also be present.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions affecting the thyroid gland can lead to symptoms such as difficulty focusing, heavy menstrual bleeding, sweating, and abnormalities in electrolyte levels.

diagnoses.name: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.description: This condition involves the overproduction of parathyroid hormone, which can lead to symptoms like weakened bones, kidney stones, menorrhagia, and abnormalities in electrolytes.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. It can cause a wide range of symptoms including abnormal electrolytes, difficulty focusing, and sweats.

diagnoses.name: Adrenal Gland Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders, such as Addison's disease, can affect the production of hormones that regulate metabolism, blood pressure, and electrolytes, leading to symptoms like sweating and menstrual irregularities.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder caused by high levels of cortisol in the blood. Symptoms might include menstrual irregularities such as menorrhagia, difficulty focusing, and electrolyte imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder that can lead to symptoms like menorrhagia. While it's primarily associated with blood clotting issues, associated complications might indirectly influence other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Myeloproliferative Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that involve an abnormal increase in blood cells produced by the bone marrow, which can lead to basophilia, abnormal electrolytes, and possibly symptoms like sweating and vision issues.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder causing the body to absorb too much iron from the diet. The excess iron is stored in various organs, particularly the liver. Symptoms include joint pain, fatigue, and, in later stages, may contribute to more complex conditions that could affect behavior and hormone levels, potentially impacting puberty.

diagnoses.name: Gaucher's disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder resulting from a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. It causes fatty substances to accumulate in certain organs, particularly the spleen and liver, leading to an enlarged liver (hepatomegaly) and spleen (splenomegaly), which could contribute to hyperferritinemia. Joint pain is a common symptom, and bone lesions can cause serious discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder affecting children that causes persistent joint pain, swelling, and stiffness. Some forms of juvenile idiopathic arthritis can lead to growth problems, potentially contributing to delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.description: While primarily a mental health condition characterized by unwanted repetitive thoughts (obsessions) and actions (compulsions), severe stress from OCD can potentially exacerbate symptoms of other underlying conditions or could correlate with other syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chromosomal disorder affecting females, where one of the X chromosomes is missing or partially missing. It can lead to a variety of medical and developmental problems including delayed puberty, though typically not associated with hyperferritinemia directly; however, associated conditions may impact overall health including the liver.

diagnoses.name: Klippel-Trenaunay Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that typically affects the development of blood vessels, soft tissues, bones, and the lymphatic system. This syndrome might not directly explain all the symptoms listed but could be associated with complex vascular anomalies and potentially indirectly lead to other symptoms due to complications.

diagnoses.name: Wilson's disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inherited disorder that causes copper to accumulate in the liver, brain, and other vital organs. Wilson’s disease might present with liver abnormalities, potentially leading to hyperferritinemia and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Anorexia nervosa
diagnoses.description: An eating disorder characterized by an abnormally low body weight, intense fear of gaining weight, and a distorted perception of weight. It can lead to severe malnutrition that affects the body's overall health and can cause delayed puberty. Anorexia can also affect mental health, potentially exacerbating or correlating with OCD tendencies.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when the body's immune system attacks its own tissues and organs. Inflammation caused by lupus can affect many different body systems, including joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs, potentially leading to a wide range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki disease
diagnoses.description: Primarily affects children. It causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body, mostly affecting the coronary arteries. Vascular anomalies are a primary concern, and while it is less common, there could be indirect associations or overlapping symptoms with those mentioned, especially in complex, atypical cases or long-term repercussions.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose).
diagnoses.reason: Can cause hyperglycemia and may contribute indirectly to periodontal disease. Menorrhagia and dyspnea could also be related.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges.
diagnoses.reason: Commonly associated with hyperglycemia. Can also lead to menorrhagia.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones.
diagnoses.reason: Can lead to menorrhagia, and hypothyroidism is sometimes associated with dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia—a condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells.
diagnoses.reason: Menorrhagia is a common cause, and can lead to dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder that slows the blood clotting process.
diagnoses.reason: Patients may experience menorrhagia and have bleeding gums, related to periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: The gradual loss of kidney function over time.
diagnoses.reason: Can cause hyperglycemia and contribute to periodontal disease. Menorrhagia and dyspnea could also be indirect symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Occurs when your body is exposed to high levels of the hormone cortisol for a long time.
diagnoses.reason: Can lead to hyperglycemia, and may have an indirect relationship with menorrhagia and periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Acromegaly
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder that develops when your pituitary gland produces too much growth hormone during adulthood.
diagnoses.reason: Can cause hyperglycemia and is associated with periodontal disease. Dyspnea can also be a symptom due to enlarged soft tissues.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the body's blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and the lymphatic system.
diagnoses.reason: Can present with hyperglycemia and periodontal disease. Menorrhagia and dyspnea can be symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Liver Disease
diagnoses.description: Includes conditions such as cirrhosis and hepatitis, which affect the liver's ability to function properly.
diagnoses.reason: May cause hyperglycemia. Periodontal disease could also be more common due to associated increased bleeding risk.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation in blood vessels, potentially leading to aneurysms and skin lesions similar to macular erythema.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including skin rashes and increased susceptibility to infection.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes swollen arteries, which can lead to aneurysms, and skin problems such as rash or erythema.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease leading to inflammation of blood vessels, which might result in symptoms like post-nasal drip.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues, leading to symptoms including aneurysms and palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the heart valves that can cause increased susceptibility to infection, aneurysms, and palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: A disease that can develop after a strep throat infection, potentially leading to heart issues (like palpitations) and skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition that can cause vasculitis, leading to symptoms such as palpitations and erythema.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An inherited disorder that affects connective tissue, potentially resulting in aneurysms and heart palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, resulting in various symptoms including erythema migrans, which might be confused with migratory patchy macular erythema.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infection due to weakened immune system, striae (stretch marks) due to skin thinning, memory problems, and anxiety are common symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Adrenal Gland Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: May cause similar symptoms as Cushing's due to hormonal imbalances, including susceptibility to infection, striae, and anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to anxiety, memory problems, and indirectly affect immune system functioning, increasing infection risk.

diagnoses.name: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)
diagnoses.reasoning: Symptoms can include anxiety, memory problems, and other stress-related symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly linked to anxiety, and chronic anxiety can lead to other health issues, including memory problems.

diagnoses.name: Hypopituitarism
diagnoses.reasoning: Deficiencies in pituitary hormone production can cause a wide range of symptoms, including increased infection risk and striae.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly causes increased susceptibility to infection. Though not directly associated with striae, treatments or associated conditions may cause them.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause memory problems and might be associated with an increased risk of infections due to immune system compromise.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily affecting mood, significant memory problems and anxiety can be side symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Blepharospasm
diagnoses.reasoning: Though a symptom itself, its presence may indicate broader neurological or systemic issues when considered alongside the other symptoms.

diagnoses: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (Primary psychiatric condition with somatic manifestations)
Hepatic diseases – Certain liver conditions may cause migratory pruritus.
Dermatological conditions – Some skin diseases can cause widespread itching.
Primary immunodeficiencies – Increased susceptibility to infection might indicate an underlying primary immunodeficiency.
Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) – This mental disorder is characterized by obsessive-compulsive behavior.
Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) – Hyperactivity and mood lability can be symptoms of ADHD.
Bipolar Disorder – Mood lability can be a symptom of bipolar disorder, which might coexist with other mental health issues like OCD.
HIV/AIDS – This condition can lead to increased susceptibility to infection and various dermatological manifestations including pruritus.
Diabetes Mellitus – Poorly controlled diabetes can lead to a higher risk of infections and sometimes causes itching due to dry skin or yeast infections.
Autoimmune disorders – Conditions like lupus can cause a wide range of symptoms including increased infection risk and mood changes.
Parasitic infections – Some parasites cause increased itching and susceptibility to other infections.
Human Papillomavirus Infection (HPV) - relates to warts
Dermatologic Conditions - related to physical sensitivities

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, potentially causing vision problems, muscle weakness, and coordination issues.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, causing a wide range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: An infectious illness usually caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, presenting with symptoms like fatigue, swollen lymph nodes, and occasionally, spleen enlargement.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders (e.g., Graves' Disease)
diagnoses.description: Diseases affecting thyroid function, which can lead to symptoms such as weight changes, sweating, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that make tears and saliva, causing dry eyes and mouth, among other symptoms such as fatigue and lymph node enlargement.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, leading to symptoms like swollen lymph nodes, fatigue, and night sweats.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A diverse group of blood cancers that include any kind of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas, with symptoms that may include enlarged lymph nodes, abdominal pain or swelling, and sweating.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune neuromuscular disease leading to varying degrees of skeletal muscle weakness, often affecting the muscles that control eye and eyelid movement, facial expression, and swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that causes severe swelling in various parts of the body, including the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airways.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare neurological disorder in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks part of its peripheral nervous system, leading to rapid-onset muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions where the immune system mistakenly attacks the body, potentially causing hearing loss, depressive symptoms, increased susceptibility to infections, hypersensitivity reactions, and sensory neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder that can cause a wide range of complications, including sensory neuropathies, increased susceptibility to infection, and hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that can lead to sensory neuropathies, a higher risk of infections, and depressive symptoms due to the overall health impact.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A virus that attacks the immune system, leading to increased susceptibility to infections, potential hearing loss due to medication or the infection itself, and sensory neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing symptoms like depression, increased infection rates due to immobility or medication, and sensory neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A deficiency in this essential nutrient can lead to sensory neuropathies, increased susceptibility to infection, and depressive symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions affecting thyroid function, which can influence susceptibility to infection, depressive symptoms, and potentially contribute to hearing loss or neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including depression, hypersensitivity reactions, increased susceptibility to infections, and sensory neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that, if untreated, can lead to hearing loss, neurological issues like sensory neuropathies, and increased susceptibility to other infections.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough hormones, leading to symptoms such as depression, increased susceptibility to infections, and possibly contributing to sensory neuropathies.

diagnoses: Autoimmune diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily associated with irregular menstruation and infertility, PCOS can also lead to hyperglycemia due to insulin resistance. It may co-occur with endometriosis, though they are distinct conditions.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.reason: Chronic bronchitis is a form of COPD, which could be exacerbated by infections. COPD may indirectly affect blood glucose levels and immune responses.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reason: Hyperglycemia is a hallmark of diabetes. Diabetes can also compromise the immune system, potentially leading to elevated levels of immunoglobulins in response to persistent infection or inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.reason: HHT, a genetic disorder leading to arteriovenous malformations, can sometimes coincide with immune system abnormalities. There's no direct link to endometriosis, hyperglycemia, or bronchitis, but the systemic nature of HHT can affect overall health.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune disease that can cause increased immunoglobulins due to the body's immune attack. SLE can affect multiple systems, including pulmonary and vascular, though specific links to arteriovenous malformations are less direct.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: This endocrine disorder, characterized by excessive cortisol, can lead to hyperglycemia. It may also affect the immune system's functioning and has been associated with an increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune disease that can lead to increased immunoglobulin levels and possibly impact the vascular system. While direct connections to arteriovenous malformations are rare, the disease can affect various organs, including the lungs.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reason: A rare disorder causing vascular inflammation, which might indirectly link to arteriovenous malformations. It can also cause systemic issues, including effects on the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy
diagnoses.reason: While primarily affecting the nervous system, this condition can lead to elevated immunoglobulin levels. There's no direct association with the other symptoms, but it reflects the complexity of systemic diseases.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.reason: A disorder characterized by low levels of serum immunoglobulins and an increased risk of infections. While primarily an immunological condition, it can have complex interactions with other bodily systems.

diagnoses.name: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
diagnoses.description: Also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy, this condition often presents like an acute myocardial infarction but without coronary artery obstruction, usually triggered by acute emotional or physical stress.

diagnoses.name: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that affects the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose). Hyperglycemia and increased susceptibility to infection are common complications.

diagnoses.name: Essential Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by persistently elevated blood pressure in the arteries without an identifiable secondary cause. It is a major risk factor for cardiovascular diseases.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A cluster of conditions that occur together, increasing the risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. These conditions can include high blood pressure, high blood sugar, excess body fat around the waist, and abnormal cholesterol levels.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol. It can lead to hypertension, hyperglycemia, and increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic kidney disease can cause hypertension and increased susceptibility to infections due to a decline in kidney function over time. It can also lead to other complications, including high blood sugar levels.

diagnoses.name: Acute Stress Reaction
diagnoses.description: A psychological condition arising in response to a terrifying or traumatic event. It can mimic symptoms of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy and can also lead to hyperglycemia due to stress.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have infrequent or prolonged menstrual periods or excess male hormone (androgen) levels. The condition can also lead to hypertension, hyperglycemia, and increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: An underactive thyroid gland that doesn't produce enough hormones, which can lead to a slower metabolism. This can indirectly contribute to conditions such as hypertension and hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Hypertension
diagnoses.description: Hypertension due to an underlying condition such as kidney disease, endocrine disorders, or the use of drugs that can increase blood pressure. It may coexist with conditions that can cause hyperglycemia and increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: CVID is a disorder characterized by low levels of several immunoglobulin classes, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections. Patients may also experience systemic complications like fibrosis and autoimmune disorders, potentially contributing to mood lability and depression.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: This condition involves a defect in the immune system that leads to an inability to kill certain bacteria and fungi, leading to chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and potentially affecting mental health.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: SLE is an autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the joints, skin, kidneys, and central nervous system. Mood lability and depression are common neuropsychiatric manifestations, and patients may have decreased immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: This autoimmune disease primarily affects salivary and lacrimal glands, leading to dryness, but can also cause systemic complications including pulmonary fibrosis. Depression and mood swings are commonly reported symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: This disease features signs and symptoms of a combination of disorders including lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Along with physical symptoms, patients may experience emotional difficulties such as depression.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis is characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body, most commonly the lungs and lymph nodes, leading to fibrosis. Neurosarcoidosis can affect the nervous system and potentially lead to mood lability and depression.

diagnoses.name: Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis
diagnoses.description: This condition is caused by an allergic reaction to inhaled dust, mold, or chemicals, leading to lung inflammation and fibrosis. Chronic exposure and illness can impact mental health, possibly contributing to mood disturbances and depression.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: These are a group of disorders wherein part of the body’s immune system is missing or does not function properly. Depending on the specific disorder, patients may experience fibrosis, mood lability, and depression.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, progressive lung disease that causes scarring (fibrosis) of the lungs. The physical limitations and chronic nature of the disease can lead to depression.

diagnoses.name: Graft Versus Host Disease (GVHD)
diagnoses.description: This disease occurs after a stem cell or bone marrow transplant, where the donated cells initiate an immune response against the recipient’s body tissues, potentially causing fibrosis and depression due to chronic illness and complex treatment regimens.

diagnoses: Diabetes Mellitus – considering the glycemic lability.
Hereditary Angioedema – due to the presentation of angioedema.
Allergic reactions or Anaphylaxis – related to hypersensitivity reactions.
Periodontitis – directly related to periodontal disease.
Migraines – given the symptom of headache.
C1 Esterase Inhibitor Deficiency – could explain both angioedema and hypersensitivity reactions.
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) – could explain the combination of symptoms due to its systemic nature.
Hypothyroidism – can lead to periodontal disease and might indirectly contribute to some of the other symptoms.
Medication-related side effects – certain medications can cause glycemic lability, angioedema, hypersensitivity reactions, and headaches.
Common Cold or Upper Respiratory Infection
Bacterial gastroenteritis (e.g., due to Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter)
Food poisoning (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus cereus)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD, for wheezing in older patients)
Urinary Tract Infection (UTI, can cause incontinence)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease or Ulcerative Colitis)
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD, can sometimes lead to vomiting and wheezing)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Peanut or other specific food allergies
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly and affect the whole body, causing incontinence, difficulty breathing (dyspnea), angioedema (severe swelling), hypotension (low blood pressure), and hives.

diagnoses.name: Urticaria
diagnoses.description: Also known as hives, urticaria is an outbreak of swollen, pale red bumps or plaques on the skin that can be triggered by an allergen. Associated symptoms can include severe itching and potentially lead to systemic reactions like hypotension and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by deep swelling beneath the skin, especially around the eyes and lips, and sometimes the genitals, hands, and feet. It can cause breathing difficulties (dyspnea) and is often accompanied by urticaria (hives).

diagnoses.name: Severe Allergic Reaction
diagnoses.description: Severe reactions to allergens can cause a range of symptoms including hives, angioedema, hypotension, and difficulty breathing (dyspnea), and in some cases, incontinence due to loss of control.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections. Symptoms can include sudden high fever, hypotension, a rash resembling a sunburn, and in severe cases, multi-organ involvement that may lead to incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: This rare condition is caused by the accumulation of mast cells, a type of blood cell mediating allergic responses. Symptoms can include skin lesions (hives), abdominal discomfort, hypotension, and anaphylaxis which might include incontinence and dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema) in various parts of the body, including the extremities, face, intestinal tract (causing abdominal pain), and airway (potential dyspnea).

diagnoses.name: Anaphylactoid Reaction
diagnoses.description: Similar to anaphylaxis but not triggered by an allergen-specific immune response. Symptoms can include hypotension, incontinence, hives, angioedema, and dyspnea. It is often associated with reactions to medications or contrast agents.

diagnoses.name: Septic Shock
diagnoses.description: A severe and potentially fatal condition that occurs when an infection leads to dangerously low blood pressure (hypotension). Symptoms can also include fever, rapid breathing (dyspnea), and in later stages, skin rashes that may resemble hives.

diagnoses.name: Acute Renal Failure
diagnoses.description: A condition where the kidneys suddenly become unable to filter waste products from the blood. In its advanced stages, it can cause symptoms such as hypotension and in rare cases, skin rash or hives, though it's less commonly associated with angioedema and incontinence.

diagnoses: Drug reaction (including allergic and intolerant reactions)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's disease
diagnoses.details: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. One of its early symptoms may include tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.details: Any intracranial tumor caused by an abnormal and uncontrolled growth of cells. It can be cancerous or non-cancerous. Symptoms can include headaches, nausea, and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic neuroma
diagnoses.details: A benign tumor on the cranial nerve that connects the ear to the brain. Symptoms can include hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance issues.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.details: High blood pressure can, in some cases, lead to headache and tinnitus, though it often presents with no symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Temporal arteritis
diagnoses.details: Inflammation and damage to blood vessels that supply the head area. Symptoms may include headache, scalp tenderness, jaw pain, and sometimes tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.details: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. Symptoms can sometimes include headache and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Medication side effects
diagnoses.details: Certain medications can produce tinnitus, headaches, and nausea as side effects.

diagnoses.name: Intracranial hypertension
diagnoses.details: Increased pressure in the skull. Symptoms can include headache, tinnitus, nausea, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Cervicogenic headache
diagnoses.details: A headache that originates from the cervical spine. Patients may sometimes experience tinnitus and nausea along with the headache.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A sudden disabling attack or loss of consciousness caused by an interruption in the flow of blood to the brain, especially through thrombosis.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A condition causing abnormal weakness of certain muscles, due to an autoimmune process where antibodies interfere with the transmission of nerve impulses to muscles.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can vary greatly depending on the brain tumor's size, location, and rate of growth.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to muscle weakness and even paralysis. Symptoms often include tingling and weakness starting in the feet and hands.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances and other sensory changes that occur about an hour before the actual headache pain begins.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of vitamin B12 can lead to neurological problems and anemic conditions, presenting with symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and cognitive disruptions.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from restricted blood flow to the back of the brain, causing symptoms like dizziness, double vision (diplopia), nausea, and coordination problems.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: An abscess caused by an infection in the brain. Symptoms can include headache, fever, weakness, and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it's a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage. Symptoms can include diplopia and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. In some cases, migraine can also lead to vertigo, tinnitus, and sensory disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In most cases, Meniere's disease affects only one ear and can also cause tinnitus and a feeling of fullness in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV)
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes intense dizziness (vertigo) especially with changes in the position of the head. It's often accompanied by other vestibular symptoms but doesn't typically include headache or tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system) that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including numbness, weakness, balance issues, and problems with vision. Tinnitus and vertigo are also possible symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Labyrinthitis
diagnoses.description: An inner ear disorder that can cause a sensation of spinning (vertigo), hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes a feeling of unbalance or instability. It can also lead to temporary nausea and vision issues.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular neuronitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the vestibular nerve, leading to severe vertigo but not typically hearing loss. It may be accompanied by nausea, dizziness, and balance difficulties, but not common with tinnitus or headache.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause a variety of symptoms depending on the tumor's location. Symptoms might include headache, numbness, hearing issues like tinnitus, and dizziness or balance issues.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA) or stroke
diagnoses.description: A temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain, causing stroke-like symptoms that can include headache, numbness in the face or limbs, difficulty speaking, and in rare cases, vertigo or tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic neuroma (Vestibular schwannoma)
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the nerve that connects the ear to the brain. Symptoms can include a gradual loss of hearing in one ear, tinnitus, and balance disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Temporal arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of blood vessels, usually in the head, that can lead to severe headaches, scalp tenderness, jaw pain, vision problems, tinnitus, and even stroke.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's Syndrome
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if not directly related to a physical health diagnosis)
Drug reaction (with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms - DRESS)
Vasculitis (specifically, Microscopic Polyangiitis or Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Thrombocytopenia)
Viral infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with renal and neurological involvement
Sjögren's Syndrome with neurological and renal involvement
Systemic Sclerosis with renal and hematologic involvement
Viral infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, HIV, Hepatitis C)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis)
Vasculitis of the central nervous system
Infectious Diseases (e.g., Hepatitis B related Polyarteritis Nodosa)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Vasculitis (e.g., microscopic polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Hepatitis B or C associated cryoglobulinemia

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.details: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause leukopenia, hemolytic anemia, pericardial effusion, and potentially nasal ulcers due to its wide range of effects on various body systems.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause hematologic abnormalities such as leukopenia and anemia, and in severe cases, can lead to pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease that typically causes dryness of the mouth and eyes, but can also cause leukopenia and hemolytic anemia. Pericardial effusion and nasal ulcers are less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.details: A disease that may present features of several connective tissue diseases, including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, which can lead to leukopenia, hemolytic anemia, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Scleroderma
diagnoses.details: A systemic autoimmune disease marked by skin thickening and hardening. It can also affect internal organs and cause telangiectasias, although leukopenia, hemolytic anemia, and pericardial effusion are less common.

diagnoses.name: Weill-Marchesani Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A rare genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue. Not commonly linked to the specific symptoms listed but could potentially lead to varied systemic manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia, potentially associated with leukopenia and other autoimmune manifestations like pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Aplastic Anemia
diagnoses.details: A condition where the bone marrow does not produce sufficient new cells to replenish blood cells. While primarily associated with pancytopenia, it can feature leukopenia and anemia, but less often affects the pericardium or causes telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
diagnoses.details: A rare, acquired, life-threatening disease of the blood characterized by the destruction of red blood cells, bone marrow failure, and blood clots. Leukopenia and hemolytic anemia are common, but pericardial effusion and telangiectasias are not directly associated.

diagnoses.name: Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome (Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia)
diagnoses.details: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation in the skin, mucous membranes, and often the organs, including the presence of telangiectasias. It's not typically associated with leukopenia, hemolytic anemia, or pericardial effusion but has diverse manifestations.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (such as Epstein-Barr virus, Cytomegalovirus)
